questions.text: All are made of dense regular collagen except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dense regular collagenous connective tissue is characterized by parallel-arranged collagen fibers that provide tensile strength in one direction. It is found in structures that require strong, unidirectional force transmission.

Structures Composed of Dense Regular Connective Tissue:

A. Ligaments → Connect bone to bone; provide stability.

B. Tendons → Connect muscle to bone; transmit muscle force.

D. Aponeurosis → Flat, sheet-like tendons; help distribute muscular force.

Structure Composed of Dense Irregular Connective Tissue:

C. Periosteum → Dense irregular connective tissue

  • Covers bones and contains fibroblasts, osteoblasts, and blood vessels.

  • Collagen fibers are randomly arranged, providing resistance to forces from multiple directions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has suffered a gunshot wound to her mid abdomen. After examining the patient's angiogram, a trauma surgeon locates the source of bleeding from pairs of veins that typically terminate in the same vein. Which of the following veins are damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Left and right hepatic veins
Ref– Read the text below
Sol:
•    The right and left hepatic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.
•    The right gastroepiploic vein drains into the superior mesenteric vein, but the left one drains into the splenic vein.
•    The right gonadal and suprarenal veins drain into the inferior vena cava, whereas the left ones drain into the left renal vein.
•    The right colic vein ends in the superior mesenteric vein, but the left one terminates in the inferior mesenteric vein.

He no more dresses himself properly and lacks initiative and drive. He also lacked inhibition and one day he was seen urinating in the dustbin of his office. Which part of the brain is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Prefrontal area
Exp: The abnormal behaviour and personality changes noticed in CEO were due to a severe lesion involving the prefrontal areas of both frontal lobes of cerebrum secondary to the depressed fracture of the frontal bone.

questions.text: The physician uses the image of the renal glomerular filtration apparatus in the image to explain to a patient his proteinuria. Which layer (labelled A–C) is the primary barrier that normally inhibits the passage of serum albumin from the glomerular capillaries into Bowman’s space?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Label B is the basement membrane, which contains anionic proteoglycan clusters that deter large, negatively charged proteins such as albumin. Label A is the capillary endothelium layer, which primarily prevents the filtration of blood cells. Label C points to podocytes, which form slits covered by slit diaphragms that further prevent the filtration of medium-sized proteins such as albumin. However, since most albumin has already been screened by the basement membrane, the podocytes are not the primary barrier, nor do they contribute equally to the glomerular barrier for protein filtration.

questions.text: The equation which is used to calculate the magnitude of the equilibrium potential of an ion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This is the Gibbs Donnan Equation.
If a membrane is freely permeable to an ion, magnitude of potential difference for that ion at equilibrium (equilibrium potential or Nernst potential) can be calculated by the Nernst Equation. 
Goldmann Hodgkin Katz equation is used to calculate the RMP.
Henderson Hasselbach equation is used to calculate the pH of a buffer solution containing given concentrations of an acid and its conjugate base.

questions.text: How does an electrical synapse differ from a chemical synapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Connexons are proteins with 6 subunits, k/a connexins, which surround a central pore. The diameter of a connexon is 2nm and the diameter of the central pore is 0.8 to 1.4nm. Connexons of one cell are aligned with connexon of a neighbouring cell forming a gap junction. Gap junctions form electrical synapses. They permit movement of ions, molecules, amino acids and sugars upto 1000 Daltons form one cell to another.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease is admitted to the ICU following a myocardial infarction (MI). He develops profound hypotension (BP: 78/52 mmHg) and bradycardia (HR: 40 bpm) despite adequate fluid resuscitation. ECG shows sinus bradycardia without any evidence of heart block. His medications include metoprolol, aspirin, atorvastatin, and ramipril. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient’s hypotensive crisis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Yohimbine

Explanation:
The patient has profound hypotension and bradycardia, likely exacerbated by beta-blocker therapy (metoprolol).
Yohimbine is an α2-adrenergic antagonist, which increases sympathetic outflow, leading to increased blood pressure and heart rate.
It is particularly useful in cases of beta-blocker-induced bradycardia and hypotension, as seen in this patient.

Why Not the Other Options?
Clonidine → α2-agonist, which further reduces sympathetic outflow, worsening hypotension and bradycardia.
Prazosin → Selective α1-blocker, which can cause further vasodilation and worsen hypotension.
Landiolol → Ultra-short-acting β1-blocker, which would further depress cardiac output, worsening bradycardia and hypotension

questions.text:
A 58-year-old female with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department with episodes of syncope and palpitations. She was recently started on a new antiarrhythmic medication for her arrhythmia.
On examination: BP: 110/70 mmHg, HR: 80 bpm (irregular)
ECG-
 
Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ibutilide

Explanation:
Torsades de Pointes (TdP) is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QT prolongation.
Ibutilide is a Class III antiarrhythmic that blocks potassium channels, delaying repolarization and significantly prolonging the QT interval, which makes it one of the most proarrhythmic antiarrhythmic drugs.
It is used for pharmacological cardioversion of atrial fibrillation but has a high risk of TdP, especially in patients with electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia).

Why Not the Other Options?
Amiodarone → Prolongs QT, but rarely causes TdP because it also has sodium channel blocking properties, stabilizing repolarization.
Lidocaine → A Class Ib antiarrhythmic, it shortens QT interval and does not cause TdP.
Quinidine → A Class Ia antiarrhythmic, also prolongs QT and increases TdP risk, but Ibutilide has the highest risk among the given options.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male with a history of focal epilepsy with secondary generalization presents to the neurology clinic for follow-up.  He reports weight gain and mild tremors over the past few months. His medication history includes a recently initiated antiepileptic drug (AED),  is known to inhibit the GABA transaminase enzyme as part of its mechanism of action. On neurological examination, there are no focal deficits, but the patient exhibits mild postural tremor.
Laboratory Findings:
•    Liver enzymes (ALT, AST): Mildly elevated
•    Ammonia level: Borderline high
Which of the following antiepileptic drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's seizure control?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Valproate

Explanation:
Valproate (Sodium Valproate/Valproic Acid) works by inhibiting GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA degradation, leading to increased GABA levels and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain.
It is broad-spectrum, effective for focal and generalized seizures, as well as absence epilepsy.

Why Not the Other Options?
Tiagabine → Increases GABA by inhibiting its reuptake, not by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
Levetiracetam → Modulates synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A), which affects neurotransmitter release but does not influence GABA metabolism.
Lamotrigine → Works by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels and does not increase GABA levels

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient with a history of persistent asthma and allergic rhinitis presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of worsening nighttime symptoms, including frequent awakenings due to cough and wheezing. His symptoms have been poorly controlled despite regular use of an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) and a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA). He has no history of smoking or cardiac disease. Pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV1/FVC ratio of 68%, and fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) is elevated.
His physician decides to add an oral agent that selectively targets a key inflammatory mediator involved in eosinophilic airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction.
Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate add-on therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Montelukast
Rationale:
This patient has uncontrolled asthma with nighttime symptoms despite being on an ICS/LABA regimen.
The elevated FeNO level suggests eosinophilic inflammation, indicating that leukotrienes are playing a significant role in his symptoms.
Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist (LTRA) that blocks CysLT1 receptors, reducing inflammation and bronchoconstriction.
It is particularly useful in patients with exercise-induced asthma, aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), and allergic rhinitis, all of which may contribute to his worsening symptoms.

Why Not the Other Options?
Theophylline –
Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor and a mild bronchodilator, but it has a narrow therapeutic index and significant side effects (arrhythmias, seizures).
It does not directly target leukotrienes, which are driving inflammation in this patient.
Ipratropium –
Ipratropium is a short-acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA), mainly used in COPD rather than asthma.
It does not play a major role in reducing eosinophilic inflammation.
Zileuton –
Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, which prevents leukotriene synthesis.
However, it requires liver function monitoring due to hepatotoxicity risks, making montelukast a more preferred option in most asthma cases

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is useful in managing cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mercaptoethane sulfonic acid (Mesna)

Explanation:
Cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide are alkylating agents used in chemotherapy that get metabolized in the liver to acrolein, a toxic metabolite that accumulates in the bladder and causes hemorrhagic cystitis.
Mesna (2-mercaptoethane sulfonic acid) is used as a uroprotective agent because it binds to acrolein and neutralizes its toxic effects, preventing bladder irritation and bleeding.
Mesna does not interfere with the antitumor activity of cyclophosphamide since it acts only in the urinary system.

Why Not the Other Options?
Acrolein –because acrolein is the actual toxic metabolite responsible for hemorrhagic cystitis. The goal is to neutralize it with Mesna, not administer it.

Oprelvekin is a recombinant IL-11 analog used to manage chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia by stimulating platelet production.
It has no role in preventing or treating hemorrhagic cystitis.
Dexrazoxane is used to prevent doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by reducing oxidative damage in the heart.
It does not protect against hemorrhagic cystitis

questions.text: Which anticoagulant does not require routine monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dabigatran

Explanation:
Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) belonging to the class of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs).
Unlike warfarin, which requires INR (International Normalized Ratio) monitoring, dabigatran has a predictable pharmacokinetic profile and does not need routine coagulation monitoring in most patients.
It is commonly used for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation (AF), venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis, and treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

Why Not the Other Options?
Warfarin –
Requires regular INR monitoring due to variable metabolism, drug interactions, and dietary influences (vitamin K intake).
Therapeutic range (INR 2-3) is crucial to balance efficacy and bleeding risk.
Lepirudin –
A direct thrombin inhibitor used in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
Requires aPTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) monitoring to adjust the dose and prevent bleeding.
Enoxaparin –
A low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that generally does not require routine monitoring in most patients.
However, in renal impairment (CrCl <30 mL/min), obesity, or pregnancy, anti-Xa level monitoring may be needed

questions.text:
A 32-year-old industrial worker is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a suspected chemical exposure in a factory dealing with plastics and metal processing. His coworkers report that he suddenly collapsed while working near a cyanide-containing solution.
On examination: Vital signs: BP 85/60 mmHg, HR 110/min, RR 30/min, Skin: Flushed, no cyanosis, ABG: Metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap, Pulse oximetry: Shows normal oxygen saturation despite severe distress, Blood gas: Lactic acidosis (high lactate levels).  The most appropriate antidote to administer in this case is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sodium thiosulfate

Explanation:
This patient presents with acute cyanide poisoning, likely due to occupational exposure.
Cyanide inhibits cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and metabolic acidosis with high lactate levels.
Despite severe hypoxia at the cellular level, pulse oximetry remains normal because cyanide does not impair hemoglobin’s oxygen-carrying capacity.
Sodium thiosulfate is a sulfur donor that converts cyanide to thiocyanate, which is then excreted renally, making it an effective antidote.

Why Not the Other Options?
Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) –
This patient has metabolic acidosis, but bicarbonate does not directly neutralize cyanide.
While it may help correct acidosis, it does not reverse cyanide toxicity.
Atropine –
Atropine is used for organophosphate poisoning (cholinergic toxicity), which presents with salivation, bradycardia, miosis, and respiratory distress.
Cyanide poisoning causes metabolic acidosis, not cholinergic toxicity.
Pralidoxime (2-PAM) –
Pralidoxime is used in organophosphate poisoning to regenerate acetylcholinesterase.
It has no role in cyanide poisoning, which affects mitochondrial respiration, not neurotransmitters

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody targets IL-6 receptors in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tocilizumab

Explanation:
Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is a key pro-inflammatory cytokine in RA, contributing to synovial inflammation, joint damage, and systemic manifestations (e.g., fatigue, anemia).
Tocilizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that blocks IL-6 receptors (IL-6R), thereby reducing inflammation and joint destruction.
It is particularly useful in methotrexate-refractory cases of moderate-to-severe RA.

Why Not the Other Options?
Rituximab –
Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that targets B cells, used in RA patients who fail TNF inhibitors or have severe seropositive RA.
While effective, it does not target IL-6.
Infliximab –
Anti-TNF-α monoclonal antibody used in RA, ankylosing spondylitis, Crohn’s disease, and psoriasis.
While TNF-α inhibitors are commonly used in RA, this question specifically asks for an IL-6 inhibitor.
Eculizumab –
Complement C5 inhibitor, used in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS).
It has no role in rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text:
A 65-year-old ICU patient with a history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease (GFR 25 mL/min) is diagnosed with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia and septic shock. His blood culture shows a multidrug-resistant (MDR) Pseudomonas strain, susceptible only to ceftolozane-tazobactam, colistin, and amikacin.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial empiric treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ceftolozane-tazobactam
Explanation:
The patient has MDR Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia with septic shock, requiring an effective, least nephrotoxic therapy.
Ceftolozane-tazobactam is a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination specifically designed to target MDR Pseudomonas with superior efficacy compared to traditional antipseudomonal β-lactams.
It is preferred over colistin and aminoglycosides, which carry a higher risk of nephrotoxicity, especially in a patient with CKD.

Why Not the Other Options?
Colistin monotherapy –
Colistin is nephrotoxic and neurotoxic, making it less favorable in a CKD patient.
Should not be used as monotherapy due to the risk of developing resistance.
Amikacin monotherapy –
Aminoglycosides should never be used as monotherapy for Pseudomonas bacteremia due to poor lung penetration and nephrotoxicity.
 Piperacillin-tazobactam –
The blood culture already showed resistance to most agents, and piperacillin-tazobactam was not among the susceptible drugs.
Using an ineffective antibiotic delays appropriate therapy and worsens mortality in septic shock.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), stage 3 chronic kidney disease (GFR 45 mL/min), and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is on metformin and sitagliptin. His HbA1c is 8.3%, and he reports fatigue and dyspnea on exertion.
Which of the following is the best next step in his diabetes management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Add empagliflozin
Explanation:
Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor) is the best choice for T2DM with CKD and HFrEF because it:
o    Reduces cardiovascular mortality in heart failure (HFrEF)
o    Slows CKD progression
o    Provides glycemic control without hypoglycemia
Sulfonylureas (glimepiride, B) increase hypoglycemia risk in CKD.
Switching to Saxaagliptin (C) is an alternative but does not provide cardiorenal protection.
•    Starting insulin (D) increases heart failure risk due to weight gain and fluid retention

questions.text: All the following microbes are associated with GBS except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune polyneuropathy that is often triggered by an infection. The immune system, after encountering certain pathogens, produces antibodies that cross-react with peripheral nerve components, leading to demyelination or axonal damage.

Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, is not a recognized trigger for GBS. While syphilis can cause neurological manifestations (e.g., tabes dorsalis, meningitis), it does not typically cause an acute post-infectious demyelinating neuropathy like GBS.

A. Campylobacter jejuni

•   One of the most common and well-established triggers of GBS

•   Molecular mimicry between bacterial lipooligosaccharides and human gangliosides leads to immune-mediated nerve damage

•   Often associated with acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) variant of GBS

B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

•   Another well-documented viral trigger of GBS

•   Particularly associated with the demyelinating subtype of GBS and can also cause facial nerve involvement

C. Mycoplasma pneumoniae

•   A known trigger of GBS, especially in children and young adults

•   Can also be associated with central nervous system manifestations along with peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: Look at the laryngoscopic image below,which statement about the use of Cidofovir in this condition is true?

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with persistent otalgia that is unresponsive to standard otitis externa treatment. He also reports purulent otorrhea and new-onset difficulty swallowing. On examination, his external auditory canal is edematous with granulation tissue at the bony-cartilaginous junction. Cranial nerve examination reveals ipsilateral facial weakness and dysphagia. A CT scan shows erosion of the temporal bone and involvement of the skull base.Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intravenous antibiotics and glycemic control
Sol:
•    Surgery is usually not the first-line treatment in malignant otitis externa. The primary approach involves aggressive IV antibiotic therapy targeting Pseudomonas aeruginosa. 
•    Surgery is reserved for cases with abscess formation or failure of medical therapy.
•    IV antibiotics (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, cefepime, or ciprofloxacin) are necessary. 
•    Strict glycemic control is also critical because diabetes is a major risk factor.
•    Steroids are contraindicated as they can worsen the infection by suppressing the immune response.

choices.text: It serves as the direct attachment site for the tensor tympani muscle, which originates from the malleus.
It acts as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle as it courses toward the medial wall of the tympanic cavity.
It is a variable structure found only in pediatric ears, typically regressing or fusing with adjacent ossicles in adulthood.
It forms the lateral boundary of the sinus tympani, thereby guiding surgical approaches to cholesteatoma removal.

questions.text: During an exploratory tympanoplasty for chronic otitis media, a surgeon carefully dissects the epitympanic space. In the process, a small, sharp bony projection is identified near the head of the malleus. The surgeon notes that this structure seems to “guide” a tendon that curves medially and recalls its importance as a surgical landmark.Based on the clinical scenario, which of the following statement regarding bony projection is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It acts as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle as it courses toward the medial wall of the tympanic cavity.
Sol:
•    Although the tensor tympani muscle is closely related to the cochleariform process, its tendon does not originate from this process; rather, the process functions as a pulley that redirects the tendon toward its insertion on the malleus.
•    The cochleariform process is a small bony prominence located near the head of the malleus. It acts as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle, which passes over it before inserting onto the medial aspect of the malleus. This anatomical detail is important during middle ear surgery to avoid inadvertent injury.
•    The cochleariform process is a consistent anatomical landmark in both pediatric and adult ears; it does not regress or fuse with adjacent ossicles over time.
•    While the sinus tympani is an important recess in the middle ear, the cochleariform process does not form its lateral boundary. Its primary role relates to the tensor tympani tendon rather than demarcating the sinus tympani.

choices.text: Tonsilloliths are incidental radiographic findings that rarely produce any symptoms.
Tonsilloliths are composed primarily of calcium salts and bacterial debris, which can contribute to halitosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic bad breath (halitosis) and intermittent throat discomfort but denies frequent episodes of tonsillitis. On examination, small, firm, yellowish deposits are palpated within the tonsillar crypts. The patient is concerned about the persistent foul odor and occasional irritation.Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tonsilloliths are composed primarily of calcium salts and bacterial debris, which can contribute to halitosis.
Sol:
•    While tonsilloliths can sometimes be asymptomatic, they are not merely incidental findings; their accumulation within the crypts can lead to noticeable symptoms like halitosis and throat discomfort.
•    Tonsilloliths form when debris (including bacteria, desquamated epithelial cells, and food particles) becomes trapped in the deep tonsillar crypts. Over time, this debris may calcify, forming stones composed mainly of calcium salts and bacterial byproducts, which are a common cause of chronic halitosis.
•    Tonsilloliths are benign and do not indicate malignant transformation; they are a result of chronic debris accumulation and inflammation.
•    Tonsilloliths can occur in individuals of any age, though they are more commonly recognized in adults, particularly those with recurrent tonsillar issues or deep crypts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of episodic vertigo lasting 20–90 minutes, often associated with a feeling of fullness in the affected ear, tinnitus (a roaring sound), and fluctuating hearing loss that initially affects low frequencies. The episodes are unpredictable, and she reports significant anxiety about when the next attack will occur. She has no history of ear infections or trauma.Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line management strategy for this patient’s condition?

A low-sodium diet and diuretics to reduce endolymphatic pressure
Sol:
•    The first-line management for Meniere’s disease usually involves conservative measures such as a low-sodium diet and diuretics. 
•    More invasive treatments (e.g., intratympanic gentamicin or surgery) are reserved for refractory cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male motorcyclist presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He complains of pain and swelling over the nasal bridge with difficulty breathing through the nose. On examination, there is bilateral nasal bone tenderness, periorbital swelling, and crepitus over the nasal dorsum. No cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak is noted. A lateral skull X-ray and CT scan confirm a linear fracture of the nasal bone without displacement.Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding this fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is a type of simple nasal bone fracture without major displacement.
Sol:
•    Chevallet fracture refers to a simple, linear nasal bone fracture that is non-displaced and typically results from low-impact trauma (e.g., minor falls, mild blunt injuries).
•    It is a linear fracture without significant displacement.
•    Often managed conservatively unless deformity or airway obstruction occurs.
•    Chevallet fractures are stable and don’t always need surgery.
•    Confused with Le Fort or zygomatic fractures. Chevallet is isolated to the nasal bone.
•    No involvement of the cribriform plate, unlike ethmoid fractures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of severe epistaxis. He reports that the bleeding is mostly unilateral, from the left nostril, and persists despite pinching the nose for 15 minutes. He denies trauma but has been taking aspirin and enalapril for years. On examination, his blood pressure is 175/95 mmHg, and active bleeding is seen in the posterior nasal cavity.Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior nasal packing with a balloon catheter
Sol:
This patient presents with severe posterior epistaxis, likely due to hypertension and anticoagulant use (aspirin). Anterior vs. Posterior Epistaxis:
o    Anterior bleeds (Kiesselbach’s plexus) are more common and easier to manage with simple compression or cautery.
o    Posterior bleeds (sphenopalatine artery) are more severe and require aggressive management, often seen in elderly patients, hypertensives, or those on anticoagulants.
o    First-line for severe posterior epistaxis that does not stop with anterior measures.
o    A balloon catheter (e.g., Epistat) can control posterior bleeding.
o    If bleeding persists, arterial ligation or embolization may be required.
Why Not the Other Choices?
o    Anterior packing → Useful for anterior epistaxis but not effective for posterior bleeds.
o    Electrocautery of Kiesselbach’s plexus → Effective for anterior epistaxis, but the patient has posterior bleeding.
o    IV Tranexamic acid → Can be adjunctive but not sufficient alone in an actively bleeding posterior epistaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with given cartilage dislocation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intubation-related trauma
Sol:
•    The arytenoid cartilages are paired cartilages in the larynx that play a crucial role in voice production and airway protection.
•    Dislocation of the arytenoid cartilage is most commonly caused by endotracheal intubation due to trauma from the tube placement.
•    It can lead to hoarseness, breathiness, and vocal fatigue.
•    Diagnosis is typically done using flexible laryngoscopy, CT, or videostroboscopy.
•    Treatment may include voice therapy, closed reduction, or surgical intervention in severe cases.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with brief episodes of vertigo triggered by turning her head or rolling over in bed. She describes a spinning sensation lasting less than a minute, without hearing loss or tinnitus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is performed, and the image below shows the patient’s eyes exhibiting upbeat and rightward torsional nystagmus when the head is turned to the right.

                                                

Based on the clinical history and the observed eye movement in the image, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Perform the positional exercise to reposition otoliths
Sol:
OPTION A
o    Central vertigo does not improve with time and usually presents with persistent nystagmus, ataxia, or neurological deficits.
o    BPPV is a peripheral cause of vertigo and is confirmed by Dix-Hallpike–induced positional nystagmus.
OPTION B
o    Vestibular neuritis presents with continuous vertigo lasting days (not episodic), and no positional triggers.
OPTION C
•    Reassurance and observation, as the condition is self-limiting – ❌ Incorrect.
•    While BPPV can resolve spontaneously, the Epley maneuver significantly speeds up recovery by repositioning otoliths.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, chronic smoker, presents with progressive hoarseness, mild dysphagia, and a palpable neck mass. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a supraglottic mass involving the epiglottis, with restricted movement but no vocal cord paralysis. MRI shows tumor infiltration into the pre-epiglottic space (PES).Which of the following structures acts as a partial barrier to superior spread of the tumor from the pre-epiglottic space?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyoepiglottic ligament
Sol:
 (a) Quadrangular membrane
o    Forms part of the lateral boundary of PES but does not restrict superior spread of tumors.
(b) Thyrohyoid membrane
o    It is part of the anterior boundary of PES but does not significantly prevent tumor spread superiorly.
(c) Hyoepiglottic ligament  
o    This ligament partially restricts superior spread of tumors from the PES to the base of the tongue.
o    However, aggressive tumors can invade the base of the tongue despite this barrier.
(d) Thyroepiglottic ligament
o    Located inferiorly, it separates PES from the paraglottic space, not the superior aspect.

questions.text: A young man have a focal seizure. His family’s description is s/o focal seizure involving left half of body.He was brought 2 hrs. questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to ER with pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. Her ABG shows Pao2 of 55mm of Hg . She uses OCP. Her vital signs are: BP- 86/44 mmHg, P- 130/ min, RR- 30 /min, SpO2 85% on room air. Her ECHO reveals RV hypokinesia. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anticoagulation plus thrombolysis

Patient is presenting with massive pulmonary embolism plus with ongoing hypotension, right
ventricular dysfunction, and hypoxemia - In this setting, the patient should receive circulatory support, anticoagulation with  fibrinolysis, if there are no contraindications.
The recommended fibrinolytic regimen is recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA). 
Heparin should be continued with the fibrinolytic to prevent a rebound hypercoagulable state with
dissolution of the clot.
If the patient had contraindications to fibrinolysis and was unable to be stabilized with vasopressor
support, referral for surgical embolectomy should be considered.

questions.text: A patient with Na+, 140; K+, 4.0; Cl-, 102; HCO3-, 12; Paco2 : 34 pH :7.26  has which of the following disorder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Steps in ABG interpretation of ABB defects:
1. See the PH : Acidosis or Alkalosis
2. Check for primary disorder : Respiratory or metabolic
3. See for compensation.
a.IF primary was respiratory process , calculate metabolic compensation. 
If primary was metabolic calculate respiratory compensation
b. If given value is within the expected value then it is a simple acid base disorder
c. If given value is not correlating with expected value then it will be a mixed disorder.

In given ABG report, Acidosis is correlating more to fall in HCO3 so its metabolic acidosis.
Expected PaCO2 = [1.5 × HCO3] +8 +-2 (Winter’s formula) that give the value of 24 to 28 mm hg. 
In given case, PaCO2 is more than expected which will suggest an additional respiratory acidosis. 
Hence, final diagnosis is Mixed Metabolic acidosis and Respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old man developed painful swelling of his left knee and gives a history of diarrhoea 3 weeks back which resolved in 3 days. Testing for gonorrhoea is negative. Reactive arthritis associated with the recent enteric infection is suspected. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Post enteric reactive arthritis (also known as Reiter syndrome) typically develops 2–4 weeks after an acute diarrheal illness. It is an immune-mediated synovitis, so the synovial fluid shows an elevated leukocyte count despite the absence of infection. Gonococcal arthritis is important to exclude in a young person presenting with acute monoarticular arthritis. Shigella sp. is the most commonly associated enteric organism associated with this syndrome, other causes include Salmonella sp., Campylobacter jejuni, Yersinia enterocolitica.Amoebic intestinal infections are not associated with reactive arthritis. People who develop this syndrome have a higher prevalence of HLA-B27 antigen, not HLADQ2, which is associated with celiac disease. This syndrome is more common in men and classically is associated with the triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis.

questions.text: Cystosarcoma phyllodes is treated by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phyllodes tumor (Cystosarcoma Phyllodes)
•    Phyllodes tumor or cystosarcoma phyllodes arise from periductal stroma and show increased cellularity of the stromal components. 
•    Commonly seen after 40 years.
•    It is a fibroepithelial tumor usually benign but it has malignant potential. 
•    The phyllodes tumor has a lobulated, leaf-like appearance.
•    In the malignant cystosarcoma phyllodes the epithelial elements are benign, but the stromal tissue is malignant. Less than 10-20% of phyllodes tumors metastasize by vascular spread, most commonly to the lung, pleura, and bone. Thus, lymph node dissection is not indicated. 
•    Local recurrence is likely.
•    A wide local excision is Treatment of choice. For a recurrent or large tumour simple mastectomy can be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by a reduction in bone mass with normal bone mineralization. It typically does not involve any major disturbance in calcium or phosphate metabolism. The serum calcium remains normal due to homeostatic regulation by parathyroid hormone (PTH) and vitamin D. Alkaline phosphatase (ALP), a marker of bone formation, also remains within normal limits because osteoporosis involves low bone turnover without increased osteoblastic activity. Therefore, both serum calcium and ALP are usually normal in osteoporosis, making option B the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

A. Calcium normal and ALP increase
This option is incorrect because an elevated ALP is typically seen in conditions involving high bone turnover, such as Paget’s disease, osteomalacia, or healing fractures, but not in osteoporosis. In osteoporosis, there is no significant increase in bone-forming activity, so ALP remains normal.

C. Calcium decreased and ALP normal
This combination suggests vitamin D deficiency or osteomalacia, where calcium absorption is impaired, leading to hypocalcemia. However, ALP is usually elevated in those cases due to increased osteoblastic activity attempting to compensate. Since calcium is normal in osteoporosis, this option is incorrect.

D. Calcium increased, ALP increased
This pattern is typically seen in primary hyperparathyroidism or malignancy-associated bone disease, where there is excessive bone resorption. In osteoporosis, calcium homeostasis is preserved and there is no excessive bone formation or resorption that would raise ALP, so this option does not fit the typical biochemical profile of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient has a past medical history of asthma on regular treatment with last exacerbation a month back. Rest all investigations are normal. Standard induction is done with propofol and fentanyl with vecuronium as muscle relaxant and cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted and confirmed in position using a capnography trace on the monitor. Shortly after the commencement of the surgery, the ventilator suddenly start showing alarm of increased peak airway pressures and the capnography waveform changes to image A. the anaesthesiologist immediately identifies the problem and intervenes and after 10 mins the capnograph changes to image B. which of the following is true about the intervention by the anesthesiologist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intraoperative bronchospasm
•    Bronchospasm is a reversible reflex spasm of the smooth muscle in the bronchi.
•    Bronchospasm is vagally mediated and caused by histamine, or one of many noxious stimuli, including cold air, inhaled irritants, and instrumentation (eg, tracheal intubation, surgical stimulation in light planes of anesthesia).
•    Bronchospasm is mediated by vagal afferents which result in an increase in cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).
•    It is more common in asthmatics.

Bronchospasm: Manifestations
•    Rapidly increasing peak inspiratory pressure (plateau pressure unchanged)
•    Wheezing
•    Slowly increasing wave on the capnograph ( shark fin appearance)
•    Decreasing exhaled tidal volumes
Bronchospasm: Acute Treatment
1) Deepen anesthetic – increase volatile anesthetic concentration 
All volatile anesthetic agents are bronchodilators
Propofol or ketamine can be used to deepen the plane as well.
Ketamine has additional Broncho dilating effect
2) Consider alternative causes of high airway pressures eg. kinked tube, endobronchial intubation, etc.
3) Inhaled β2 -agonists – delivered to the inspiratory limb of the circuit through a metered dose inhaler or nebulized. If the severity of bronchospasm prohibits delivery of inhaled beta agonists, consider infusions of IV agonists such as terbutaline or epinephrine.
4) Consider administering intravenous steroids

questions.text: A patient was observed in her room alone talking loudly and gesticulating, this is probably an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hallucination  


Hallucination refers to perception without sensory input. The patient is having a conversation and gesticulating to someone who is not in the room. Delusion (choice A) refers to false belief (not perception) that is not amenable to reason. In obsessive-compulsive behaviour (choice C), the patient recognizes the irrationality of the compulsion, but not engaging in it causes extreme anxiety. In panic states, the patient experiences extreme anxiety, usually immobilizing or forcing him/her to escape from the situation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman tells the physician that she must drive the route she takes home from work each day at least three times to be sure that she did not hit an animal in the road. Of the following, the most appropriate long-term pharmacological management for this patient is

Correct Answer (D)

An Antidepressant agent 

The most effective pharmacological treatment for this patient who has obsessive– compulsive disorder is an antidepressant, particularly a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. Antipsychotics, antianxiety agents, and lithium are less appropriate than an antidepressant for this patient.

questions.text: Following 3 neurotransmitter systems are involved in the patho-physiology of panic disorder except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dopamine 

The major neurotransmitter systems that have been implicated are those for norepinephrine, serotonin, and GABA. Serotonergic dysfunction is quite evident in panic disorder, and various studies with mixed serotonin agonist–antagonist drugs have demonstrated increased rates of anxiety. Such responses may be caused by postsynaptic serotonin hypersensitivity in panic disorder. Preclinical evidence suggests that attenuation of local inhibitory GABAergic transmission in the basolateral amygdala, midbrain, and hypothalamus can elicit anxiety-like physiological responses. The biological data have led to a focus on the brainstem (particularly the noradrenergic neurons of the locus ceruleus and the serotonergic neurons of the median raphe nucleus), the limbic system (possibly responsible for the generation of anticipatory anxiety), and the prefrontal cortex (possibly responsible for the generation of phobic avoidance). Among the various neurotransmitters involved, the noradrenergic system has also attracted much attention, with the presynaptic α2-adrenergic receptors, particularly, playing a significant role. Patients with panic disorder are sensitive to the anxiogenic effects of yohimbine in addition to having exaggerated MHPG, cortisol, and cardiovascular responses.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of a "barking" cough, stridor, and mild fever. The child appears irritable but is alert, and vital signs are stable. On examination, you note that the child has a hoarse voice and that stridor is present both at rest and with agitation. The radiograph is shown below. 

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Steeple sign is classic sign of Croup/LTB. The steeple sign is characterized by a narrowing of the upper airway, specifically in the subglottic region (the area below the vocal cords and above the trachea). On a frontal neck X-ray, this narrowing creates a shape that resembles a church steeple or a pencil tip, with a pointed or tapered appearance.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant presents with developmental regression and frequent, chaotic seizures characterized by a distinctive pattern on electroencephalogram (EEG). The EEG reveals hypsarrhythmia. The child has been experiencing multiple clusters of spasms daily, which have proven resistant to initial treatments. The clinical team is considering specific medication options to manage this severe form of epilepsy.

Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating hypsarrhythmia associated with infantile spasms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone)

Hypsarrhythmia is typically associated with infantile spasms, a type of seizure disorder that often requires targeted treatment. ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) is considered the drug of choice for managing infantile spasms due to its efficacy in reducing seizure frequency and improving developmental outcomes.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of persistent respiratory symptoms and frequent lung infections. The child's medical history reveals a diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency and growth delays. Genetic testing confirms the presence of a specific autosomal recessive disorder. 
Which of the following is an autosomal recessive disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cystic Fibrosis

Cystic Fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to the production of thick, sticky mucus that affects the respiratory and digestive systems.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old newborn is found to have a markedly elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 100 IU/ml on routine newborn screening. To confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause of this condition, additional investigations are required.
Which of the following investigations should be performed to confirm congenital hypothyroidism and further evaluate the thyroid gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radionucleotide Scan

Congenital hypothyroidism often results from either thyroid dysgenesis or thyroid hormone biosynthesis defects. A radionucleotide scan is a critical diagnostic tool in this context, as it helps to evaluate the presence, size, and function of the thyroid gland. It can reveal whether the thyroid gland is present and functioning (or absent), which helps differentiate between different causes of congenital hypothyroidism, such as thyroid agenesis, ectopic thyroid tissue, or functional abnormalities.

Therefore, a radionucleotide scan is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism and assess the thyroid gland's condition.

5 yrs or till 21 yrs of life

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a 5-day history of abdominal pain, which he describes as crampy and diffuse. The pain has been worsening and is now severe enough to interfere with his daily activities. In addition to abdominal pain, his parents have noticed that he has developed a rash on his legs and buttocks. On examination, the child has palpable purpura, primarily on the extensor surfaces of his legs and buttocks, along with some mild swelling in the same areas. The boy also reports intermittent joint pain, particularly in his knees and ankles, and has been feeling unusually fatigued. 
What would be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Glucocorticoids

questions.text:
A 2-month-old female infant with poor feeding and failure to gain weight is seen for evaluation. She is fed 24 kcal/oz of appropriately prepared infant formula. She was born at 39 weeks’ gestation, and her birth weight was 3 kg. She failed her newborn hearing screening. She had one hospital admission with vomiting and diarrhea at 6 weeks after birth. Her weight is currently at the third percentile, and her height is at the fifth percentile. Her cardiac examination reveals no murmur, and her chest is clear to auscultation. The rest of her physical examination findings are unremarkable.
Laboratory data are shown:

Sodium 134 mEq/L (134 mmol/L)

Potassium 3.2 mEq/L (3.2 mmol/L)

Chloride 110 mEq/L (110 mmol/L)

Bicarbonate 14 mEq/L (14 mmol/L)

Blood urea nitrogen 10 mg/dL (3.6 mmol/L)

Creatinine 0.2 mg/dL (18 μmol/L)

Glucose 90 mg/dL (5.0 mmol/L)

Urine

pH 7.0

Specific gravity 1.015

Urinalysis with microscopy Normal

Sodium 60 mEq/L (60 mmol/L)

Potassium 10 mEq/L (10 mmol/L)

Chloride 55 mEq/L (55 mmol/L)

Of the following, the MOST likely diagnosis for this child is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The infant in the vignette has failure to thrive and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. The higher-than-expected urinary pH and positive urine anion gap favors a diagnosis of distal renal tubular acidosis.

questions.text: A 2 years old child has proximal muscle weakness, and has frequent falls during running. He is unable to stand from squatting position. Following is his muscle biopsy image. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Death by 3rd decade

Child has typical Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Muscle biopsy in Duchenne muscular dystrophy typically reveals dystrophin deficiency or absence. Histological findings often include muscle fiber degeneration, necrosis, and replacement with fibrous and fatty tissue. Immunohistochemical staining can show a lack of dystrophin at the sarcolemma, confirming the diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
